articles.title: Young people on benefits to be offered construction and hospitality work
articles.summary: The government says it will fund training and work experience for 350,000 not in work or education.
articles.content:
Young people on benefits to be offered construction and hospitality work

14 minutes ago Share Save Kathryn Armstrong Share Save

Getty Images

Young people on benefits will be offered job opportunities in industries such as construction and hospitality in a bid to tackle rising youth unemployment. The government will fund 350,000 training and work experience placements, and will guarantee 55,000 jobs in areas it says are in the highest need from spring 2026. Funding will come from the £820m announced by Chancellor Rachel Reeves in the Budget last month to finance a raft of measures aimed at getting young people off Universal Credit and into work. Work and Pensions Secretary Pat McFadden said the plans would help out-of-work young people "make something of their lives". But the Tories blamed the Budget for driving youth unemployment up.

The number of 16-24-year-olds not in employment, education or training - known as Neets - has been trending upwards since 2021, with the latest figures showing nearly a million young people are now not earning or learning. The government had already announced in September that it intended to provide guaranteed work placements for 18-21-year-olds who had been out of work or education for longer than 18 months, with those not taking up the offer without good reason facing losing their benefits. The new training and work experience opportunities for young people on Universal Credit will be in sectors including construction, hospitality, and health and social care, the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) announced on Saturday.

It said that the government-backed jobs will not necessarily be in the same sectors, but that they would be in the following regions: Birmingham and Solihull

the East Midlands

Greater Manchester

Hertfordshire and Essex

Central and eastern Scotland

South-west and south-eastern Wales The government says that 900,000 young people in total who are on Universal Credit and are looking for work will be given a "dedicated work support session", followed by four additional weeks of "intensive support". An employment coach will then refer them to one of six pathways: work, work experience, apprenticeship, wider training, learning, or a workplace training programme with a guaranteed interview. The government expects more than 1,000 young people to start a job in the first six months of the scheme. "Every young person deserves a fair chance to succeed. When given the right support and opportunities, they will grasp them," McFadden said. He described the funding as "a downpayment on young people's future". But shadow work and pensions secretary Helen Whately criticised other measures announced in the Budget, saying: "The Chancellor's tax hikes are driving up youth unemployment, snatching a career from a generation of young people." She added: "This scheme is nothing more than taking with one hand to give with the other." Further plans are expected to be set out in the coming week as the government prepares to publish its national youth strategy.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a government initiative to provide training, work experience, and guaranteed jobs to 350,000 young people on benefits, addressing youth unemployment on a large scale. The plan includes substantial funding and structured support pathways, aiming to improve employment prospects and social inclusion for a significant portion of the youth population across multiple regions. This represents a meaningful policy effort with broad societal impact and clear substance.
articles.personality_title: Government to train 350,000 young people for jobs in construction and hospitality
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many young people aged 16 to 24 are currently not working, studying, or training. This group is often called NEET, which stands for 'Not in Employment, Education, or Training.' The number of NEET young people has been rising since 2021, reaching nearly one million. This situation worries the government because it means many young people are missing chances to build their futures.

**What happened** – The government announced a new plan to help 350,000 young people who receive benefits find training and work experience in areas like construction, hospitality, health, and social care. Starting in spring 2026, 55,000 jobs will be guaranteed in regions with the greatest need, including places like Birmingham, Greater Manchester, and Scotland. Young people will get support from employment coaches who guide them through options such as apprenticeships, training programs, and guaranteed interviews.

**Impact** – This plan is important because it offers real chances for young people to gain skills and find jobs in industries that need workers. By focusing on specific regions and sectors, the government hopes to reduce youth unemployment and help young people become more independent. It also shows a clear commitment with £820 million set aside to fund these efforts.

**What’s next step** – The government will continue to develop this program and share more details soon as part of a national youth strategy. They aim to start placing young people in jobs quickly, with over 1,000 expected to begin work in the first six months. The program will also provide ongoing support to help young people keep their jobs and build careers.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The government’s new plan will train and support 350,000 young people on benefits to gain work experience and jobs in key industries, aiming to reduce youth unemployment across several regions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le gouvernement forme 350 000 jeunes aux métiers de la construction et de l’hôtellerie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Beaucoup de jeunes de 16 à 24 ans ne travaillent pas, n’étudient pas et ne suivent pas de formation. On les appelle les NEET, pour « ni en emploi, ni en éducation, ni en formation ». Ce nombre augmente depuis 2021 et atteint près d’un million. Cette situation inquiète le gouvernement car elle empêche ces jeunes de préparer leur avenir.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé un plan pour aider 350 000 jeunes bénéficiaires d’aides sociales à suivre des formations et des stages dans des secteurs comme la construction, l’hôtellerie, la santé et le social. À partir du printemps 2026, 55 000 emplois seront garantis dans des régions en forte demande, comme Birmingham, Manchester et l’Écosse. Les jeunes seront accompagnés par des coachs emploi qui les guideront vers des options comme les apprentissages, les formations ou les entretiens garantis.

**Impact** – Ce plan est important car il donne aux jeunes de vraies chances d’apprendre un métier et de trouver un emploi dans des secteurs qui manquent de main-d’œuvre. En se concentrant sur certaines régions et branches, le gouvernement espère réduire le chômage des jeunes et les aider à gagner en autonomie. Il s’agit d’un engagement clair avec 820 millions de livres réservés à ce projet.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement va continuer à développer ce programme et donner plus d’informations bientôt dans le cadre d’une stratégie nationale pour la jeunesse. Il prévoit de commencer rapidement à placer les jeunes en emploi, avec plus de 1 000 jeunes attendus dans les six premiers mois. Le programme offrira aussi un soutien continu pour aider les jeunes à conserver leur emploi et construire leur carrière.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le nouveau plan du gouvernement formera et soutiendra 350 000 jeunes bénéficiaires pour qu’ils acquièrent une expérience professionnelle et un emploi dans des secteurs clés, afin de réduire le chômage des jeunes dans plusieurs régions.
articles.personality_title_es: El gobierno capacitará a 350,000 jóvenes para trabajos en construcción y hostelería
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos jóvenes de 16 a 24 años no están trabajando, estudiando ni en formación. A este grupo se le llama NEET, que significa 'Ni en Empleo, Educación o Formación'. Este número ha ido aumentando desde 2021 y ya casi llega a un millón. El gobierno está preocupado porque estos jóvenes pierden oportunidades para prepararse para el futuro.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció un plan para ayudar a 350,000 jóvenes que reciben beneficios a obtener capacitación y experiencia laboral en sectores como construcción, hostelería, salud y cuidado social. Desde la primavera de 2026, se garantizarán 55,000 empleos en regiones con más necesidad, como Birmingham, Manchester y Escocia. Los jóvenes recibirán ayuda de entrenadores laborales que los guiarán hacia opciones como aprendizajes, programas de formación y entrevistas garantizadas.

**Impacto** – Este plan es importante porque ofrece oportunidades reales para que los jóvenes aprendan habilidades y encuentren empleo en sectores que necesitan trabajadores. Al enfocarse en regiones y sectores específicos, el gobierno espera reducir el desempleo juvenil y ayudar a los jóvenes a ser más independientes. Además, ha destinado 820 millones de libras para financiar estas acciones.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno seguirá desarrollando este programa y dará más detalles pronto como parte de una estrategia nacional para la juventud. Esperan que más de 1,000 jóvenes comiencen a trabajar en los primeros seis meses. También ofrecerán apoyo continuo para que los jóvenes mantengan su empleo y construyan una carrera.

**Frase clave** – El nuevo plan del gobierno capacitará y apoyará a 350,000 jóvenes beneficiarios para que obtengan experiencia laboral y empleos en sectores clave, buscando reducir el desempleo juvenil en varias regiones.
